case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay City, Bombay v. Legal representatives of Navinchandra Mafatlal

facts.text: This is an appeal by the Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay City, Bombay, on a certificate granted by the High Court of Bombay against its judgment and order dated March 18, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Hidayatullah, J. This is an appeal by the Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay City, Bombay, on a certificate granted by the High Court of Bombay against its judgment and order dated March 18, 1954.

facts.text: High Court answered three questions referred by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal in favour of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: By that judgment the High Court answered three question referred by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: The assessee was Mafatlal Gagalbhai, whose legal representative Navinchandra Mafatlal had died and present respondents are legal representatives of Navinchandra Mafatlal.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee in the cases was Mafatlal Gagalbhai, whose legal representative, Navinchandra Mafatla, had also since died and the present respondents are the legal representatives of Navinchandra Mafatlal.

facts.text: Concerned with assessment of income of Mafatlal Gagalbhai for accounting years 1941 and 1942 corresponding to assessment years 1942-43 and 1943-44.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned in this case with the assessment of the income of Mafatlal Gagalbhai for the accounting years 1941 and 1942, companyresponding to the assessment years 1942-43 and 1943-44.

facts.text: Mafatlal Gagalbhai assessed under section 23(3) of Income-tax Act on total income of Rs. 3,76,539 for 1942-43 and Rs. 4,42,693 for 1943-44.

anchor.surface_text: In these two years Mafatlal Gagalbhai was assessed under section 23 3  of the Income-tax Act on a total income respectively of Rs. 3,76,539 and Rs. 4,42,693.

facts.text: In first year no appeal was preferred.

anchor.surface_text: In the first year, numberappeal was preferred, and in the second, the appeals to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Tribunal were unsuccessful.

facts.text: In second year appeals to Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal were unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: In the first year, numberappeal was preferred, and in the second, the appeals to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Tribunal were unsuccessful.

facts.text: In accounting year 1941 Mafatlal Gagalbhai held 12,485 ordinary shares and 2,500 preference shares in Gagalbhai Jute Mills Ltd. Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: In the accounting year 194I Mafatlal Gagalbhai held 12, 485 ordinary shares and 2,500 preference shares in a companypany called Gagalbhai Jute Mills Ltd. Calcutta.

facts.text: In accounting year 1942 he held ordinary shares less by 300 and same number of preference shares.

anchor.surface_text: In the accounting year 1942 he held ordinary shares which were less by 300 and the same number of preference share.

facts.text: No dividend declared at general meetings for years ending March 31, 1941 and March 31, 1942 on ordinary or preference shares.

anchor.surface_text: At the general meeting of the companypany, for the years ending March 31, 1941 and March 31, 1942, numberdividend was declared either on the ordinary or on the preference shares.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer passed order on February 20, 1947 applying section 23A to the company deeming Rs. 5,71,072 for AY 1941-42 and Rs. 10,00,411 for AY 1942-43 as distributed dividend.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the companypany, the Income-tax Officer passed order on February 20, 1947, applying section 23A to the companypany and holding that Rs. 5,71,072 for the assessment year 1941-42 and Rs. 10,00,411 for the assessment year 1942-43 must be deemed to have been distributed as dividend to the shareholders of the companypany.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer reopened assessments of Mafatlal Gagalbhai for two years and added Rs. 4,48,502 and Rs. 7,96,082 as deemed distributed on ordinary shares under section 34.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of these orders, the Income-tax Officer reopened the assessments for the two years, of Mafatlal Gagalbhai, and added Rs. 4,48,502 and Rs. 7,96,082 as amounts deemed to have been distributed to him on the ordinary shares.

facts.text: Company appealed against section 23A order to Appellate Assistant Commissioner who agreed with Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany appealed against the order under section 23A to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who agreed with the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Legal representative of assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner against demand for tax on additional sums but order confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: The legal representative of the assessee also appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner against the demand for tax on the additional sums, but the order was companyfirmed.

facts.text: Tribunal by order dated July 29, 1948 held undistributed profits first to preference shareholders then balance to ordinary shareholders.

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal by its order dated July 29, 1948, took the view that the undistributed profits had number been properly distributed and that there should have been first a distribution among the preference shareholders and the balance thereafter must be deemed to have been distributed amongst the ordinary shareholders.

facts.text: Legal representative of assessee withdrew appeals to Tribunal with leave after seeing Tribunal order in company appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent also had appealed to the Tribunal against the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner but seeing the order of the Tribunal in the appeals of the companypany, it was realised that if the appeals were to be proceeded with, there would be additional levy of tax if the matter was referred back to the Department in accordance with the decision in the appeals of the companypany. The legal representative of the assessee, therefore, withdrew the appeals with the leave of the Tribunal.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer reopened assessment of Mafatlal Gagalbhai without notice under section 34, reassessed by reducing ordinary deemed dividends and including preference deemed dividends to give effect to Tribunal directions.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter went back to the Department on the order of the Tribunal in the appeals of the companypany, the Income-tax Officer reopened the assessment of Maftlal Gagalbhai without sending a numberice under section 34 of the Income-tax Act. He reassessed the income of Mafatlal Gagalbhai, reducing the amounts which were deemed to be distributed in respect of the ordinary shares, and included the dividends which, he held, must be deemed to have been distributed in respect of the preference share.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued notice of demand after reassessment.

anchor.surface_text: He added a numbere to the order of assessment that this action was taken to give effect to the directions of the Tribunal land issued a numberice of demand.

facts.text: Legal representative appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner but dismissed as no appeal lay under section 30.

anchor.surface_text: The legal representative of Mafatlal Gagalbhai then appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner but it was held that numberappeal lay under section 30 of the Income-tax Act and the appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: Tribunal confirmed Appellate Assistant Commissioner view that no appeal lay.

anchor.surface_text: This view of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was companyfirmed by the Tribunal

facts.text: Tribunal stated case and referred questions to High Court under section 66(1) regarding Income-tax Officer orders dated January 23, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: but the Tribunal at the instance of the legal representative of Mafatlal Gagalbhai stated a case and referred the following question to the High companyrt under section 66 1  for its decision Whether the orders of the Income-tax Officer dated January 23, 1950, are appealable ? Whether it was incumbent upon the Income-tax Officer to take action under section 34 of the Indian-tax Act before he revised the assessment on January 23, 1950 ? If the answer to question No.  2  is in the affirmative, whether the bar of limitation specified in section 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act would apply to the inclusion in the total income of a shareholder of the dividend which is deemed to have been distributed under section 23A 1  of the Act ?

facts.text: Reference heard by Chagla C.J. and Tendolkar J.

anchor.surface_text: The reference was heard by Chagla, C.J. and Tendolkar, J.

facts.text: High Court held section 23A is procedural or computation section not giving right to Department to make assessment.

anchor.surface_text: both held that section 23A was either a procedural section or a companyputation section but did number give the right to the Department to make an assessment.

facts.text: High Court followed earlier decision in S. G. Cambatta v. Commissioner of Income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: In doing so they purported to follow an earlier decision of the same High Court reported in S. G. Cambatta v. Commissioner of Income-tax,

facts.text: Supreme Court decision bound by its earlier pronouncement in Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax that assessment under section 23A requires section 34.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this matter is numberlonger open to argument after the decision of this companyrt in Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax. Dealing with 23A and section 34 it was observed by this companyrt as follows It seems to us that the Tribunal was wrong in the view that it took. ... The assessment, therefore, has to be made under the other provisions of the Act, including section 34, authorizing assessments.

issues.text: Whether section 23A is a self-contained section which brings to charge dividends deemed to have been distributed without requiring assessment proceedings under section 34?

anchor.surface_text: He contended that section 23A is a self-contained section and brings to charge dividends deemed to have been distributed and, in terms does not require any other assessment proceedings either by way of section 23 or section 34 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the observation in Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax that section 23A does not provide for assessment but requires other provisions including section 34 is obiter?

anchor.surface_text: It was contended before us that this must be regarded as obiter and not applicable to the present case. It was also stated that it proceeded on a concession by the Solicitor-General. In our opinion both these contentions are without foundation.

issues.text: Whether notice under section 34 is a condition precedent to reassessment action including inclusion of deemed dividends under section 23A?

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the opinion that action under section 34 was necessary, and that since notice was a condition precedent to such action, the act of the Income-tax Officer in bringing to charge the income without issuing a notice under section 34 was illegal.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that the Tribunal in its order had earlier said as follows Where an order is passed under section 23A I  of the Indian Income- tax Act in the case of a companypany it is number necessary that action under section 34 of the Act has to be taken if necessary for the purpose of revising the assessment made on a shareholder. The fact that action was taken under section 34 in the past does number mean that action under section 34 has to be taken under the law as it stands. The relevant part of section 23A I  is as follows and thereupon the proportionate share thereof of each shareholder shall be included in the total income of such shareholder for the purpose of assessing his total income. The provision is mandatory and has numberhing to do with the provisions of section 34 of the Act.

holdings.text: Section 23A does not provide for any assessment being made and requires that the assessment be made under the other provisions of the Act, including section 34.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this matter is numberlonger open to argument after the decision of this companyrt in Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax. Dealing with 23A and section 34 it was observed by this companyrt as follows It seems to us that the Tribunal was wrong in the view that it took. ... The assessment, therefore, has to be made under the other provisions of the Act, including section 34, authorizing assessments.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The matter is concluded by the binding precedent of this Court in Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, which held that section 23A merely deems distribution of dividend but does not authorize assessment without section 34.

holdings.text: The pronouncement in Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax that assessment under section 23A requires section 34 is not obiter dicta but a binding decision of the Court.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended before us that this must be regarded as obiter and number applicable to the present case. It was also stated that it proceeded on a concession by the Solicitor-General. In our opinion both these contentions are without foundation. No doubt, the Solicitor-General conceded the point, but the court went on to state its own view of the matter and the question appears to have been raised and answered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Although the Solicitor-General conceded the point, the Court independently stated its view after considering the issue, making it a direct holding rather than obiter.

holdings.text: In view of the clear pronouncement of this Court in Sardar Baldev Singh, the decision of the High Court under appeal must be regarded as correct.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the clear pronouncement of this companyrt, in our opinion, the decision of the High Court under appeal must be regarded as companyrect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The High Court's judgment aligns with the binding Supreme Court precedent on the necessity of section 34 for assessments involving deemed dividends under section 23A.

holdings.text: The bar of limitation under section 34 applies to the inclusion in the total income of a shareholder of the dividend deemed to have been distributed under section 23A(1).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this matter is numberlonger open to argument after the decision of this companyrt in Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax. Dealing with 23A and section 34 it was observed by this companyrt as follows It seems to us that the Tribunal was wrong in the view that it took. ... The assessment, therefore, has to be made under the other provisions of the Act, including section 34, authorizing assessments.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since assessment requires action under section 34 as per precedent, the limitation provisions of section 34 necessarily apply.

holdings.text: Notice under section 34 is a condition precedent to reassessment action including inclusion of deemed dividends under section 23A.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this matter is numberlonger open to argument after the decision of this companyrt in Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax. Dealing with 23A and section 34 it was observed by this companyrt as follows It seems to us that the Tribunal was wrong in the view that it took. ... The assessment, therefore, has to be made under the other provisions of the Act, including section 34, authorizing assessments.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 34 governs such assessments and requires notice as affirmed by precedent.

precedents.citation: S. G. Cambatta v. Commissioner of Income-tax

anchor.surface_text: S. G. Cambatta v. Commissioner of Income-tax, where it was stated as follows section 23A is a mandatory section and lays down ruled of companyputation in companyputing the total income of the shareholder referred to in that section per Chagla, J.  as he then was . Stone, C.J., observed in that case In my opinion looking at the scheme of the Act, section 23A is a procedural section and number a charging section. It may be pointed out that the Tribunal in its order had earlier said as follows Where an order is passed under section 23A I  of the Indian Income- tax Act in the case of a companypany it is number necessary that action under section 34 of the Act has to be taken if necessary for the purpose of revising the assessment made on a shareholder. The fact that action was taken under section 34 in the past does number mean that action under section 34 has to be taken under the law as it stands. The relevant part of section 23A I  is as follows and thereupon the proportionate share thereof of each shareholder shall be included in the total income of such shareholder for the purpose of assessing his total income. The provision is mandatory and has numberhing to do with the provisions of section 34 of the Act.

precedents.case_name: S G Cambatta v Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: section 23A is a procedural section and not a charging section; lays down rules of computation in computing the total income of the shareholder
precedents.cited_holding: section 23A is a procedural section and not a charging section

precedents.citation: Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax

anchor.surface_text: Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax. Dealing with 23A and section 34 it was observed by this companyrt as follows It seems to us that the Tribunal was wrong in the view that it took. The learned Solicitor-General companyceded that this is so. We are unable to agree that an assessment companyld be made under section 23A. That section does number provide for any assessment being made. It only talks of the fictional income being included in the total income of the shareholders for the purpose of assessing his total income. The assessment, therefore, has to be made under the other provisions of the Act, including section 34, authorizing assessments. It was companytended before us that this must be regarded as obiter and number applicable to the present case. It was also stated that it proceeded on a companycession by the Solicitor-General. In our opinion both these companytentions are without foundation. No doubt, the Solicitor-General companyceded the point, but the companyrt went on to state its own view of the matter and the question appears to have been raised and answered. In view of the clear pronouncement of this companyrt, in our opinion, the decision of the High Court under appeal must be regarded as companyrect.

precedents.case_name: Sardar Baldev Singh v Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: section 23A does not provide for assessment; the fictional dividend must be included in total income but assessment has to be made under other provisions of the Act including section 34
precedents.cited_holding: That section does number provide for any assessment being made. It only talks of the fictional income being included in the total income of the shareholders for the purpose of assessing his total income. The assessment, therefore, has to be made under the other provisions of the Act, including section 34, authorizing assessments.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this matter is numberlonger open to argument after the decision of this companyrt in Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax. anchor.surface_text: It was contended before us that this must be regarded as obiter and number applicable to the present case. It was also stated that it proceeded on a concession by the Solicitor-General. In our opinion both these contentions are without foundation. No doubt, the Solicitor-General conceded the point, but the court went on to state its own view of the matter and the question appears to have been raised and answered.
In view of the clear pronouncement of this court, in our opinion, the decision of the High Court under appeal must be regarded as incorrect.
